quoteFirst: But our Passengers’ Amendment Act of 1855, which came into operation on the 1st October of that year, made some important advances towards the law of the United States. The principal alterations introduced by this Act, beyond the regulations of 1852, were, that the number of passengers was limited; the age of a “statute adult” reduced from
quoteLast: years; a distinction was made between the upper and lower passenger deck; increase of space was allowed to passengers; mail steamers were exempted under special rules; the dietary scale improved; the amount of detention-money increased; and the emigrant runners placed under more efficient control.
title: History of merchant shipping and ancient commerce, Volume 3 (of 4)
author: Lindsay, W. S. (William Schaw), 1816-1877

quoteFirst: , enters upon its last quarter; on the 18th, at 7:23 p. m., new moon; and on the 26th, at
quoteLast: , enters upon its first quarter. Is nearest to the earth on the 7th, at 8:48 a. m., and farthest away on the 23d, at 7:48 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, October 1884, No. 1
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: the sharp warning came from the lookout: "Iceberg right ahead." Instantly the engines were reversed and the helm was put hard a-starboard. A few seconds earlier and she might have cleared.
title: An Unsinkable Titanic: Every Ship its own Lifeboat
author: Walker, John Bernard, 1858-

quoteFirst: A specific sum was assumed ($21,500,000), and this was distributed among the States in specific portions. Thus modified, it passed the Senate, July 22d, by the close vote of
quoteLast: ; and the House, July 24th, by thirty-four to twenty-eight.
title:
The Student's Life of Washington; Condensed from the Larger Work of Washington Irving
For Young Persons and for the Use of Schools
author: Irving, Washington, 1783-1859

quoteFirst: And so, at eleven forty-five that evening, had Rollo. For a full three-quarters of an hour he waited, scanning the face of each new arrival with the anxious scrutiny of a lost dog seeking its master; but at
quoteLast: the last faint flicker of hope had died away. A girl may be a quarter of an hour late for supper. She may be half an hour late.
title: The Man Upstairs and Other Stories
author: Wodehouse, P. G. (Pelham Grenville), 1881-1975

quoteFirst: We steered along the shore N. by W. at the distance of between three and four leagues, having from
quoteLast: , and ten fathom water: in the offing we saw two islands, which lie in latitude 16° S., and about six or seven leagues from the main.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. II. Being the Second of the First Voyage
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Banks, Joseph, 1743-1820 [Contributor]; Hawkesworth, John, 1715?-1773 [Editor]

quoteFirst: They shook hands good humouredly, tossed for corners, Sayers proving the winner, and then at once commenced peeling to the bitter frost and south-easterly breeze. The colours, a neat French grey for Sayers, and blue and white spots for Benjamin, were now tied to the stakes, the usual preliminaries were quickly settled, and at
quoteLast: “time” was called. The betting round the ring was very slight, 2 to 1 being freely offered, but takers were scarce at anything under 5 to 2.
title:
Pugilistica: The History of British Boxing, Volume 3 (of 3)
Containing Lives of the Most Celebrated Pugilists; Full Reports of Their Battles from Contemporary Newspapers, With Authentic Portraits, Personal Anecdotes, and Sketches of the Principal Patrons of the Prize Ring, Forming a Complete History of the Ring from Fig and Broughton, 1719-40, to the Last Championship Battle Between King and Heenan, in December 1863
author: Miles, Henry Downes, 1806-1889

quoteFirst: This decline in American tonnage is, it must be added, only relative, whether the comparison be made with other countries or with our own past. The returns show a carrying capacity in our ships more than twentyfold that of 1789, and three times that of 1807; when, on the other hand, it exceeded in the ratio of
quoteLast: that of 1829, twenty-two years later. This interest is peculiarly subject to fluctuations; some of which in the past have been less explicable than the one it is now undergoing.
title: Lippincott's Magazine of Popular Literature and Science, Volume 17, No. 098, February, 1876
author: Various

quoteFirst: This circle of stones on the level ground was made up of angular rocks such as are scattered on the immediate surface. It measures ten by eleven feet in diameter inside; fifteen by seventeen feet from the top of the circle; and twenty-two by twenty-three feet over all. The top of the highest stones was from
quoteLast: inches above the middle of the space enclosed which as before stated, seemed to be on a level with the outside, all measuring being east to west and north to south respectively. Among the rocks was found a chipped piece of jasper or brown chalcedony.
title: The Archaeology of the Yakima Valley
author: Smith, Harlan Ingersoll, 1872-1940
